results.title: Google Stadia Wants You to Replace Your Video Game Console. Don’t.
results.abstract: The search giant’s new console-free gaming service is a neat concept. But there are bugs and too many unknowns.

multimedia.caption: Google launched its Stadia cloud service that allows people to play console-quality video games on a web browser or smartphone.

results.title: T-Mobile’s Longtime C.E.O., John Legere, Will Step Down
results.abstract: Mr. Legere was credited with reviving the telecommunications company. He has been instrumental in navigating T-Mobile’s pending merger deal with Sprint.

multimedia.caption: T-Mobile’s chief executive, John Legere, will step down at the end of April after his contract expires.
multimedia.copyright: Alex Wong/Getty Images

results.title: Stop! Don’t Charge Your Phone This Way
results.abstract: You might want to think twice before plugging in at an airport or on the train.

results.title: SoftBank and Line Corp. Seek to Create a Japanese Internet Giant
results.abstract: Fresh off a multibillion-dollar loss on WeWork, SoftBank plans to shore up its domestic business with a big bet on Japan’s leading messaging app company.

results.title: A 17-Mile Hike to Unite San Francisco
results.abstract: A motley alliance decided a single trail could unite this divided city. A sixth-generation native sets out to walk it.

results.title: TikTok’s Chief Is on a Mission to Prove It’s Not a Menace
results.abstract: Alex Zhu, the head of the Chinese-owned viral video app, is trying to assuage Washington’s fears. “I am quite optimistic,” he said.

results.title: Ford Wants to Sell You an Electric S.U.V. It’s Called a Mustang.
results.abstract: Automakers have made battery-powered cars largely to meet environmental rules. Now they’re putting more skin in the game.
des_facet: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

multimedia.caption: The Mustang Mach E was unveiled on Sunday. It is set to come to auto showrooms next year.

results.title: WeWork May Lay Off Thousands
results.abstract: The beleaguered office space company is said to be planning to cut its work force by at least a third in a bid to stabilize its business.
results.byline: By PETER EAVIS and MIKE ISAAC

multimedia.caption: A WeWork office in Midtown Manhattan. The company could announce layoffs as early as this week.
multimedia.copyright: An Rong Xu for The New York Times

results.title: HP Rejects Xerox Takeover Bid
results.abstract: The cash-and-stock offer “significantly undervalues HP and is not in the best interests of HP shareholders,” company officials wrote.
